isis.stitle: TSI 92-05-02 - On-Vehicle Poppet Readjustment for TRW TAS Power Steering Gears

subjectgroup.subject: On-Vehicle Poppet Readjustment for TRW TAS Power Steering Gears

geninfo.para: This TSI applies to all vehicles with power steering.

Poppets are pressure unloading valves set to trip just before a full turn is reached in each direction. When this procedure is operating correctly, system pressure will be reduced before the axle stop contacts the axle stop screw in both directions.
Why poppets need to be adjusted:

item.para: Steering gear being installed on a different truck.
Steering axle stop bolt(s) were bent or broken.
Steer axle U-bolt(s) were bent or broken.

geninfo.para: To determine if the poppets require readjustment or if they are performing properly, install a Power Steering System Analyzer between the power steering pump and the steering gear. If poppet readjustment is required, you can leave the Analyzer in the system to verify that the following procedure is completed properly.

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE

note.para: This procedure will work in most cases with at least 1-3/4 steering wheel turns from each side of center. If you're making a large reduction in wheelcut and this procedure does not work, refer to GROUP 05 - STEERING for detailed information to internally set the poppets.

step1.para: Set axle stops to Navistar's specifications. Refer to GROUP 02 - FRONT AXLE.
Start the engine and allow the vehicle to idle for 5 to 10 minutes to warm the hydraulic fluid. Shut off the engine.
If a new poppet adjusting screw and nut are being used, turn the screw into the non-sealing end of the jam nut until the device end of the screw is flush with the nut ( Figure 1).

Your steering gear will have either a fixed stop bolt or an adjusting screw. If the adjusting screw is already part of the steering gear, back the nut off the adjusting screw until it is flush with the end of the adjusting screw.

Make sure the engine is off and the front wheels of the vehicle are straight ahead. Remove and discard the poppet fixed stop bolt (if equipped) and washer from the lower end of the housing ( Figure 2).
If the unit has a poppet adjusting screw and sealing nut that need to be replaced, remove and discard them.

With a 7/32 inch Allen wrench, turn the adjusting screw and sealing nut assembly without rotating the nut on the screw into the housing until the nut is firmly against the housing. Tighten the sealing nut against the housing ( Figure 3).

figure.caption: Figure 3. Turn Adjusting Screw Assembly Into Housing

step1.para: Refill the system reservoir with approved hydraulic fluid ( Figure 4). Refer to GROUP 10 - LUBRICATION for the proper hydraulic fluid.

caution.para: Do not mix fluid types. Mixing of transmission fluid, motor oil, or other hydraulic fluids will cause seals to deteriorate faster.

step1.para: Block the rear wheels and set the parking brake.
Place a jack under the center of the front axle and jack up the front end of the vehicle so the steer axle tires are off the ground ( Figure 5).

Start the engine and run at idle speed. Note which output shaft timing mark is nearest the housing piston bore. Turn the steering wheel in the direction that makes this timing mark move toward the adjusting screw just installed. Turn in this direction until axle stop contact is made. Pull hard on the steering wheel (put 30 lbs. rim pull on a 20-inch-diameter steering wheel) after the axle stop is contacted. This will prepare the upper poppet for setting ( Figure 6).

figure.caption: Figure 6. Push Upper Poppet Out To Prepare It For Setting

step1.para: To set the poppet, turn the steering wheel in the opposite direction (end of timing mark away from adjusting screw) until the other axle stop is contacted. Pull hard on the steering wheel (put 30 lbs. rim pull on a 20-inch-diameter steering wheel). Release the steering wheel and shut off the engine ( Figure 7).

caution.para: Do not hold the steering wheel at full turn more than 10 seconds at a time; the heat build-up at pump relief pressure may damage steering components.

step1.para: Loosen the sealing nut and back off the adjusting screw until 1 inch past the nut. Tighten the sealing nut against the housing ( Figure 8).

Start the engine and let idle. Turn the steering wheel in the original direction (end of timing mark toward adjusting screw) until axle stop contact is made. Hold the steering wheel in this position (30 lbs. rim pull) for 10 seconds, then release ( Figure 9). Repeat this hold and release process as many times as necessary while completing step 12.

With steering wheel held at full turn, loosen the jam nut and hold it in place with a wrench. Turn the adjusting screw in (clockwise) using finger-pressure only - don't use a ratchet - until the Allen wrench comes to a stop. Do not attempt to turn it in further.Stop the turn-in process each time the driver releases the steering wheel; continue turning only while the steering wheel is being held at a full turn. Back off the adjusting screw 3-1/4 turns and tighten sealing nut to 33-37 ft. lbs. torque ( Figure 10).

caution.para: Do not hold the steering wheel at full turn more than 10 seconds at a time; the heat build-up at pump relief pressure may damage steering components.
The length of the adjusting screw beyond the nut must be no more than 1-1/16 inch for proper thread engagement.

note.para: The length of the adjusting screw beyond the sealing nut may vary for each vehicle.

svcproc.para: The poppets have now been completely set. Check the power steering reservoir fluid level and fill if required ( Figure 11).
